Hsuan Chou
UX Designer at Athlon NYC
Mar 6

Communicating with Developers

The relationship between a designer and a developer are like frenemy, we need each other, but we cannot help feeling frustrated at each other sometimes: “why you just cannot get me!?” I believe sometimes they think we (designers) are always too naive and didn’t realize how much time it will take to actualize our designs.

I like to compare the two of the roles to the way men and women think. Providing actual numbers (even code) is a better method than asking them to get that ‘feeling”.

There are tools I’ve tried:

1. Invision Inspect, Sympli and Zeplin

These tools are all similar, in a way. All show the number of colors, margin and enables developers to download assets. Sympli and Inspect show the concept of layers. Inspect is native in InVision, powered by Craft. I think InVision has ambitions to integrate all the working tools in one. It’s a good all-in-one tool if not for the many bugs and often crashes.

The best feature of Sympli is when you select the color and font on the list, it will reflect on the artboard that where this value is. This is a very useful feature, considering a similar app like Zeplin shows color which shouldn’t on the screen, but I just can’t find where that color is.

Zeplin is the most common used tools for translating Sketch to developers, and the interface is the cutest out of the three, so it’s still the one I am using it so far.

2. UBS (User Behavior Specification)

Usually made in Slides or Keynotes, UBS writes the introduction of the product which includes main screens and main user flows.

It’s helpful, but easy to overwrite 200 pages for one product. Not only is it painful to write, I believe it’s a suffer to read too. It’s rely on the writer that can he/she have the point and lead the reader to know the products step by step but still keep it short. Also, it would be good to use InVision and animations as an additional supplement.

As a writer, my tool of preference is Keynote as it is easier to edit but not everyone use Mac, so clients usually ask us to use Slides.

3. Sit closer with developers!

Real communication is hard to replace. Sometimes, emails and conversations go back and forth several times. It’s best to scoot over, point to one screen and say “this part is different from the original design. Let’s test it out together.”
